title: Grande Casse
text:
The Grande Casse (3,855 m) is the highest <a href="mountain">mountain</a> of the <a href="Vanoise%20Massif">Vanoise Massif</a> in the <a href="Graian%20Alps">Graian Alps</a> in the region of <a href="Savoie">Savoie</a>, France. It is located in the heart of the <a href="Vanoise%20National%20Park">Vanoise National Park</a>, near the village of <a href="Pralognan-la-Vanoise">Pralognan-la-Vanoise</a>, which is about 25 km southeast of the nearest town, <a href="Mo%C3%BBtiers">Moûtiers</a>. It has a steep 600 m high north face. The other sides of the mountain are more gentle, mostly consisting of broken rocks. A high ridge connects it to the nearby peak of <a href="Grande%20Motte">Grande Motte</a>.
The ridge connecting the Grande Casse and the Grande Motte is the <a href="Drainage%20divide">watershed</a> between the <a href="Tarentaise%20Valley">Tarentaise Valley</a> in the north and <a href="Maurienne">Maurienne</a> valley to the south.
Climbing.
Despite its height it has a relatively easy <a href="normal%20route">normal route</a> to the summit. Climbers usually start from the "Les Grands Couloirs" glacier and ascend the southwest side of the mountain. The north face is an <a href="extreme%20skiing">extreme skiing</a> destination.
The <a href="first%20ascent">first ascent</a> was made by <a href="William%20Mathews%20%28mountaineer%29">William Mathews</a> along with guides <a href="Michel%20Croz">Michel Croz</a> and E. Favre via the southwest face on 8 August 1860. The north face was climbed on 6 August 1933 by the Italians Aldo Bonacossa and L. Binaghi.
The Refuge Félix Faure (2,516 m), used for the normal route, is located at the <a href="Col%20de%20la%20Vanoise">Col de la Vanoise</a>.
